moves.1. d4: Black takes advantage of a series of blunders by white to earn a win through mate
moves.1... d5: A queen opening. I choose to match white in the middle of the board and see how the opening progresses.
moves.3. Bf4: WHite is ahead in development and pressing me firmly
moves.3... a6: I protect against the attack on C2 and the fork to follow
moves.4. Nh3: White continues to develop his minor pieces, I am lagging seriously behind
moves.4... Nf6: So I step up my efforts to catchup in development
moves.5. g3: I see white building a castle
moves.6. Bg2 Bg7 7. O-O O-O: The castles constructed, I breathe a sigh of relief. I do not like my King so exposed
moves.8. Na4: A move I do not fully understand. White is trying to ....do what.....????????????
moves.8... Re8: I continue my castle development and my opneing sequence
moves.9. Qd3: So white brings the Queen. This gives white control of much of mys side of the board I suppose, so in one sense, white is well ahead.
moves.9... Nbd7: Undaunted, I continue to open the game
moves.10. Qd2: See, this is what I call a wasted move. White could have done this a move earlier, and then I would have had to react then, bit I did not worry about it until now.
moves.10... Ne4: OK, so I threaten the queen and force a retreat
moves.11. Qe3: Well at least that is what I thought would occur
moves.11... e5: So instead I challenge the bishop
moves.12... Nxe5: So this is a bit planned. I can be foiled if white captures my Knight in an exchange
moves.13. f3: BUt white does not, instead, white gives me an opening.
moves.13... Nc4: this is interesting, now white has to make a small decision - a knight for a queen, I think not...
moves.14. Qb3: not really a ah rd choice, but the solution white selects plays white into a fork
moves.14... Ned2: A double knight attack is a bit formidable
moves.16... Bf8: with a 2 point advantage, I can now tackle the queen
moves.17. Nc5: so this is a good situation for me because the knight is pinned.
moves.18... bxc5: now taking this knight was a bit foolish because the queen was in a position to be pinned to the castle - there is another term for this, but I can't recall what that is...
moves.19. b3: in any event white does not recognize the danger
moves.19... Nb6: I give him an out....by running away
moves.20. Bc1: still not seeing the danger, white tries to build an attack
moves.22. Qd4: Now this is  HUGE blunder by white certainly ensuring a quick end to the game.
moves.22... Bxd4+: bye bye queenie...an 18 point lead and check to boot
moves.23. Nf2: what is next....white retreats and black...
moves.23... Bb7: begins to set up the end game.
moves.24. e3: a futile attempt to lure me into retreating...
moves.24... Bxe3: bye bye paywn - just a mere foot soldier - cannon fodder
moves.25. Bxe3: this is not going to help. White should be preserving pieces not sacrificing them
moves.25... Rxe3: this is calculated. I need the pawn up a row, the g3 pawn gone, and the queen on d5
moves.27. Be2: like I am going to allow a bishop interfere with my plans
moves.28. Bf1: finally white is getting the picture. But this retreat locks the king in for me and makes my life easier.
moves.29. Nd1: this is actually a very interesting move. White fails to see the danger of capturing the castle. In the event he does so, I capture the knight and bring my pawn up to guard the f2 square. With the bishop on g1, I am almost home dry
moves.29... Qd5: finally, step three and a move or two away from mate
moves.30. Nxe3: white makes the fatal mistake of capturing the castle afterall
moves.30... dxe3: the f2 square is closed to retreat for white. The king is captured, there is nothing white can do.
moves.31. c4: in a futile attempt to distract me, white tries to threaten my queen.
moves.31... Qh1#: On to Mate. A well planned and executed end game.
